metadata.sermon_title: The Scroll That Would Not Be Shredded
metadata.sermon_start_end: Every social organization, if it prospers and lasts a long time, is prone to complacency and self-indulgence and illusion about its true character and future. And when a social organization gets distorted in such a way, there is need to re-form and re-formulate and re-shape according to its true character. [...] That word cannot be shredded. It has staying power because it tells the truth that our society can hardly bear. And it cannot be shredded! It cannot!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific Bible passage. It treats the narratives of 2 Kings 22 and Jeremiah 36 as historical illustrations for a general theme of 'Reformation.' It does not identify what is unique to these texts that cannot be found elsewhere; instead, it uses them to support a general concept of 'truth-telling.'
quotes: In our readings we have these two narratives, one in the book of Kings and one in the book of Jeremiah, closely related to each other.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the Josiah narrative or the Jehoiakim narrative and isolate the specific theological 'point' of that text that distinguishes it from general ideas of church reform.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic historical reconstruction of the 7th century BCE, but it remains at the level of storytelling. There is no evidence of engagement with the original languages or the specific theology of the Deuteronomistic history beyond a surface reading.
quotes: It was in the seventh century BCE, about 620, during the reign of King Josiah, about twenty kings after King David and King Solomon in Jerusalem.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exegesis by exploring the specific covenantal terminology in the Hebrew text to move beyond the 'spiffy temple' imagery.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part of the sermon, showing a broad knowledge of the humanities and zeitgeist. It specifically targets Western democratic capitalism and consumer greed. However, it occasionally slips into generalities about 'hospitality' and 'generosity.'
quotes: The gospel truth entrusted to the church is not congruent with but too comfortable with the common assumptions of Western democratic capitalism, with our consumer greed and our military anxiety.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Make the application even more concrete by addressing specific local congregational habits rather than broad systemic critiques of 'capitalism' or 'the greed system.'

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is strictly partitioned into historical blocks (I, II, III) followed by application blocks (IV, V). The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' in one movement; the text serves as a springboard for the preacher's contemporary analysis.
quotes: All of this is not ancient history... It is rather about the church in our time...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'leap' from then to now. Allow the contemporary critique to emerge directly from the unfolding of the biblical narrative itself.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The category of 'misery' is well-developed as 'toxic self-indulgence' and 'anxiety.' Redemption is present as the 'good news of God's love.' However, the sermon leans heavily on man as the subject of reform rather than God's act of redemption.
quotes: It is an urgent need to recover the church from its toxic self-indulgence and complacency.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure that redemption is not merely a human 're-forming' but a divine act that precedes human gratitude.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon takes the 'two ways' seriously, specifically the 'temporal loss' of a society or church that perishes due to its own greed. It presents a clear choice between the 'greed system' and 'neighborliness.'
quotes: The king acted with contempt and imagined that when he got rid of the scroll he could get rid of the summons and the warning... you cannot get rid of the scroll.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Balance the 'temporal loss' (societal collapse) with the 'eternal loss' Dekker mentions to heighten the theological stakes.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned toward the end, but primarily as an ethical example ('Jesus is the good neighbor') rather than the ontological telos or the God-man of the two-natures doctrine. Grace is present but borders on a general 'goodness of God.'
quotes: Jesus is the good neighbor because he is the one who shows mercy. And we are the ones, after him, who believe...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Move beyond Jesus as a moral exemplar of neighborliness to Christ as the one who is our life outside of ourselves.

8_depth_and_length.findings: With an estimated duration of approximately 14-15 minutes, the sermon falls short of Dekkerâ€™s 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true homiletical 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and dogmatic sections to allow the text to speak more fully before moving to application.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its lack of focus on a single specific Bible passage and its insufficient length. It functions more as a thematic speech on 'Reformation' and 'Social Justice' than a scriptural exposition. While the contemporary critique is sharp and the 'two ways' are presented with seriousness, the Christology is largely exemplary rather than telic.
strengths: Strong awareness of the zeitgeist and the 'misery' of contemporary Western culture.
Effective use of the 'two ways' by presenting the serious consequences of ignoring the 'scroll.'
Clear, sober language that avoids sentimentality.
weaknesses: Uses multiple texts as illustrations for a theme rather than expounding one specific pericope.
Exegesis remains at a narrative surface level without deep theological or linguistic engagement.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This text is an adequate religious speech but, according to Dekker's strict formal criteria, it is not yet a 'sermon' because it lacks a single specific biblical foundation and the necessary breadth for depth.
